canonical_explanation.text: Household electrical supply in India is alternating current (AC) at 220V. Domestic circuits have three wires: live wire (red/brown), neutral wire (black/blue), and earth wire (green/yellow-green). Appliances are connected in parallel so each gets full voltage and can work independently. Fuses and circuit breakers are safety devices that break the circuit when current exceeds safe limits. Earthing protects users from electric shock by providing a low-resistance path to ground. The electric meter measures energy consumption in kilowatt-hours (kWh) or units. Power rating tells how much electrical energy an appliance uses per second.
rules: Live wire (red/brown): carries current to appliance
Appliances are connected in parallel in homes.
Fuse: thin wire that melts when current is too high
Circuit breaker: switch that trips when current exceeds limit
Earthing provides path for leaking current to ground.
Electric meter measures energy in kWh (units)

questions.question_text: In India, the domestic electrical supply voltage is:
questions.explanation_correct: The domestic electrical supply voltage in India is 220V. This is the standard voltage used in households across the country, as specified by the Indian electrical standards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The domestic electrical supply voltage in India is not 110V, 440V, or 12V. These voltages are used in other countries or for specialized applications, but not for the general household electrical supply in India, which is 220V.

questions.question_text: The color of the live wire in new color coding is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Brown. In the new color coding for household electrical wires, the live wire is colored brown.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The live wire is not blue, green, or black. The live wire carries the main electrical current in a household circuit, and in the new color coding system, it is colored brown to easily identify it.

questions.question_text: The earth wire is connected to:

options.text: The metal body of the appliance

questions.explanation_correct: The earth wire is connected to the metal body of the appliance to provide a safe path for any leakage current. This ensures that the metal body does not become live, preventing electric shocks to users.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire is not connected to the heating element, the fuse, or the switch. The earth wire's purpose is to provide a low-resistance path to the ground, so that any leakage current flows to the earth instead of through the user's body. Connecting the earth wire to the metal body of the appliance is the correct way to implement earthing for safety.

questions.question_text: A fuse is a safety device that:

options.text: Melts and breaks circuit when current is too high

questions.explanation_correct: A fuse is a safety device that melts and breaks the circuit when the current is too high. This stops the flow of excess current and prevents damage to the electrical appliance or wiring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fuse is not designed to increase current flow. Instead, it is a safety device that stops the flow of electricity when the current is too high. This prevents overheating and fires in the electrical circuit. The fuse is made of a thin wire that melts and breaks the circuit when the current goes above a safe level.

questions.question_text: In household wiring, appliances are connected in:
questions.explanation_correct: In household wiring, appliances are connected in parallel so that each appliance gets the full voltage from the electrical supply and can work independently. This allows one appliance to be used without affecting the others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Appliances are not connected in series in household wiring. In a series connection, if one appliance stops working, the entire circuit is broken and no other appliances can work. In a parallel connection, each appliance has its own path to the power source, so they can work independently.

questions.question_text: Why is earthing important for electrical appliances?
questions.explanation_correct: Earthing is important to protect users from electric shock. It provides a low-resistance path to the ground, allowing excess current to flow safely away from the appliance and the user.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Earthing does not increase the power or voltage of the appliance. It also does not save electricity - the amount of electricity used by the appliance depends on its power rating, not the earthing. Earthing is important to protect the user by providing a safe path for excess current to flow to the ground, preventing electric shocks.

questions.question_text: If one appliance fails in a parallel circuit, other appliances:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, each appliance is connected directly to the power source. If one appliance fails, the other appliances continue to work because they have their own separate connections to the power source and are not affected by the failure of one appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If one appliance fails in a parallel circuit, the other appliances do not stop working. This is because each appliance has its own separate connection to the power source, so the failure of one appliance does not affect the others. The other appliances continue to receive the full voltage and can work independently.

questions.question_text: A circuit breaker is better than a fuse because:

options.text: It can be reset after tripping

questions.explanation_correct: A circuit breaker is better than a fuse because it can be reset after it trips, whereas a fuse needs to be replaced after it blows. This allows the circuit breaker to be reused, making it more convenient and cost-effective in the long run.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct. A circuit breaker is not necessarily cheaper than a fuse, and it does not use more electricity. It also does not last forever, as it can trip and need to be reset over time. The key advantage of a circuit breaker is that it can be reset instead of needing to be replaced like a fuse.

questions.question_text: A 1000 W heater is used for 2 hours. The energy consumed is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 2 units. The power rating of the heater is 1000 W, and it was used for 2 hours. To calculate the energy consumed, we multiply the power (1000 W) by the time (2 hours), which gives us 2000 W-h or 2 units of energy consumed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not correctly calculate the energy consumed. Option B) 500 units is too high, as 1000 W for 2 hours would only be 2 units. Option C) 2000 units is also too high, as 1000 W for 2 hours is 2 units. Option D) 1 unit is too low, as the correct amount of energy consumed is 2 units.

questions.question_text: What should be the fuse rating for an appliance that draws 3 A current?
questions.explanation_correct: The fuse rating should be 5 A (option C) because the appliance draws 3 A of current. Fuses are designed to break the circuit when the current exceeds a safe limit, so the fuse rating should be slightly higher than the actual current drawn by the appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not suitable for this appliance. 1 A (option A) is too low and would trip the fuse even during normal operation. 2 A (option B) is also too low. 15 A (option D) is much higher than the actual current drawn, so it would not provide the necessary protection for the appliance.

questions.question_text: In India, household electricity supply is DC (direct current).
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is false because in India, the household electricity supply is alternating current (AC), not direct current (DC). AC is the standard electrical supply for homes and buildings in India, not DC.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The household electricity supply in India is AC, not DC. AC stands for alternating current, which means the flow of electric charge periodically reverses direction. This is different from DC, or direct current, where the electric charge flows in a single direction. The Indian household electricity supply is AC at 220 volts, not DC.

questions.question_text: The neutral wire completes the electrical circuit.
questions.explanation_correct: The neutral wire completes the electrical circuit by providing a return path for the current back to the power source. This allows the current to flow through the appliance and back to the source, completing the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The live wire carries the electrical current from the power source to the appliance, while the neutral wire provides a return path for the current. The neutral wire is necessary to complete the circuit, so the statement that the neutral wire completes the electrical circuit is correct.

questions.question_text: Double insulated appliances do not require earthing.
questions.explanation_correct: Double insulated appliances do not require earthing because they have two layers of insulation to protect the user from electric shock. The outer layer acts as a backup in case the inner layer fails, so there is no need for a direct connection to the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think that double insulated appliances need earthing, but this is not the case. Double insulation provides two layers of protection, so there is no need for an additional earth wire to protect the user. The appliance is designed to be safe even if one layer of insulation fails, so earthing is not required.

questions.question_text: The fuse is always connected in the live wire.
questions.explanation_correct: The fuse is always connected in the live wire because the live wire carries the current from the power source to the appliance. If there is an overload or short circuit, the fuse in the live wire will melt and break the circuit, protecting the appliance and the user from damage or electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fuse is not connected in the neutral wire. The neutral wire completes the circuit and carries the current back to the power source. The fuse is always placed in the live wire to cut off the supply of current in case of an overload or short circuit, which can be dangerous.

questions.question_text: The three wires in domestic circuits are live, neutral, and ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The third wire in domestic circuits is the earth wire, which provides a low-resistance path to the ground. This helps protect users from electric shocks if there is a fault in the appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The third wire is the earth wire, not the live or neutral wire. The earth wire is green or yellow-green in color and it helps protect people from electric shocks by providing a safe path to the ground. The three wires in a domestic circuit are live, neutral, and earth.

questions.question_text: A ___ melts and breaks the circuit when excess current flows.
questions.explanation_correct: A fuse is a safety device that melts and breaks the circuit when excess current flows through it. This prevents damage to the electrical wiring and appliances in your home.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fuse'. A fuse is a small metal strip or wire that is designed to melt and break the circuit when too much current flows through it. This protects the wiring and appliances from getting damaged by the excess current. The other options like 'circuit breaker' or 'earthing' do not melt to break the circuit.

questions.question_text: Electric energy is measured in ___, also called units.
questions.explanation_correct: Electric energy is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh), which is the amount of energy consumed when 1 kilowatt (1000 watts) of power is used for 1 hour. This unit is commonly used to measure the total energy used by electrical appliances and devices in homes and businesses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is kilowatt-hours (kWh). This is the unit used to measure the total electric energy consumed by a household or appliance. It takes into account both the power rating (in kilowatts) and the time of usage (in hours). The electric meter in your home measures the energy use in kWh, which is then used to calculate your electricity bill.

questions.question_text: ___ provides a low-resistance path for leaking current to flow to the ground.
questions.explanation_correct: Earthing provides a low-resistance path to the ground, which helps divert any leaking current away from the user. This protects people from getting an electric shock if there is a fault in the appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'Earthing'. Earthing is important in household electrical circuits because it creates a low-resistance path for any leaking current to flow to the ground. This prevents the current from passing through the user's body, which could cause an electric shock. Other electrical safety devices like fuses and circuit breakers do not provide this low-resistance path to the ground.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of current in a household circuit:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is live wire from the mains, the appliance, and then the neutral wire back to the mains. This is because the live wire carries the current from the power source to the appliance, and the neutral wire provides a path for the current to return to the power source, completing the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be appliance, live wire from mains, and neutral wire back to mains. This is wrong because the current needs to flow from the live wire to the appliance and then back through the neutral wire to the power source. The appliance cannot be placed before the live wire, as it needs the live wire to provide the current.

questions.question_text: Arrange these events when a short circuit occurs:
questions.explanation_correct: When a short circuit occurs, excess current starts flowing through the circuit. This causes the fuse wire to heat up and melt, breaking the circuit safely. This sequence of events prevents damage to the electrical system and keeps users safe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If a short circuit occurs, the excess current will flow first. This will cause the fuse wire to melt, which will then break the circuit safely. The circuit is not broken until the fuse wire melts, so the correct sequence is: excess current flows, fuse wire melts, circuit is broken safely.

questions.question_text: The frequency of AC supply in India is:
questions.explanation_correct: The frequency of AC power supply in India is 50 Hz, which means the alternating current changes direction 50 times per second. This is the standard frequency used for household electricity in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The frequency of AC power supply in India is not 60 Hz, 100 Hz, or 25 Hz. These are not the standard frequencies used for household electricity in India. The correct frequency is 50 Hz, which is the standard frequency used for AC power supply in the country.

questions.question_text: The color of the neutral wire in new color coding is:
questions.explanation_correct: The neutral wire in the new color coding is blue. This is because the neutral wire carries the return current from the appliance back to the power source, and the blue color is used to represent the neutral wire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The neutral wire is not brown, green, or red. The correct color for the neutral wire in the new color coding is blue. This is to differentiate the neutral wire from the live wire (brown or red) and the earth wire (green or yellow-green).

questions.question_text: The earth wire is usually:
questions.explanation_correct: The earth wire is usually green or yellow-green in color because it is used to provide a safe path for any excess current to flow to the ground, protecting users from electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire is not brown, blue, or red in color. These colors are used for the live wire (red/brown) and the neutral wire (black/blue). The earth wire is specifically colored green or yellow-green to indicate its purpose of providing a safe path to the ground in case of an electrical fault.

questions.question_text: A fuse wire is made of:

options.text: An alloy of tin and lead

questions.explanation_correct: Fuse wires are made of an alloy of tin and lead because this alloy has a low melting point. When the current flowing through the fuse exceeds the safe limit, the fuse wire melts and breaks the circuit, protecting the appliance and household wiring from damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper, iron, and aluminum are not suitable for fuse wires because they have higher melting points compared to the tin-lead alloy. The low melting point of the tin-lead alloy is crucial for the fuse to function properly and break the circuit when the current is too high.

questions.question_text: One unit of electrical energy equals:
questions.explanation_correct: One unit of electrical energy is equal to one kilowatt-hour (kWh). This is because electrical energy is measured in terms of power (in watts) over time (in hours), and one kilowatt-hour represents the energy consumed when one kilowatt of power is used for one hour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A, 'one watt-hour', is incorrect because a watt-hour is a smaller unit of electrical energy than a kilowatt-hour. Option C, 'one megawatt-hour', is too large for household electrical use. Option D, 'one joule', is a unit of energy but not the specific unit used for measuring household electrical energy, which is the kilowatt-hour.

questions.question_text: AC stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, 'Alternating Current'. AC stands for alternating current, which is the type of electrical current used in household electrical supply. In AC, the flow of electric charge periodically reverses direction, unlike direct current (DC) where the flow is always in one direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect. 'Alternate Circuit' (A) is not the full form of AC. 'Active Current' (C) and 'Applied Current' (D) are not standard terms used to describe the type of household electricity supply. Alternating current (AC) is the correct term for the type of electrical current used in Indian homes.

questions.question_text: The main function of a switch is to:
questions.explanation_correct: The main function of a switch is to open or close the circuit, allowing or cutting off the flow of electricity. Switches control the electrical connection, turning appliances on and off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The switch does not increase current, as that would make the appliance work harder and could be dangerous. Switches also do not store electricity, as that is the job of batteries and capacitors. Switches also do not convert AC to DC, as that requires special circuits and components.

questions.question_text: Which wire carries current from the power station to the appliance?
questions.explanation_correct: The live wire carries the electrical current from the power station to the appliance. This is the wire that has the 220V electrical potential, allowing the appliance to function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The neutral wire is used to complete the circuit and allow current to flow back to the power station, but it does not carry the main current to the appliance. The earth wire provides a path to ground in case of electrical faults, but it does not carry the normal current to the appliance either. The 'ground wire' is another term for the earth wire.

questions.question_text: The power rating of an appliance indicates:

options.text: How much electrical energy it uses per second

questions.explanation_correct: The power rating of an appliance indicates how much electrical energy it uses per second. This is important because it tells you how much power the appliance needs to operate properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The power rating does not indicate how long the appliance can run, as that also depends on the energy source and the appliance's power consumption. The power rating also does not indicate the appliance's weight or size, as those are physical characteristics unrelated to its electrical power requirements.

questions.question_text: A short circuit occurs when:

options.text: Live and neutral wires touch each other directly

questions.explanation_correct: A short circuit occurs when the live and neutral wires touch each other directly. This creates a low-resistance path, allowing a large amount of current to flow through the circuit, which can be dangerous and damage the appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A short circuit does not occur when the circuit is too long, when the appliance is switched off, or when the voltage is too low. These conditions may affect the functioning of the appliance, but they do not lead to a short circuit. A short circuit happens when the live and neutral wires touch each other, creating a low-resistance path for the current to flow.

questions.question_text: Why are appliances in homes connected in parallel rather than in series?

options.text: So each gets full voltage and works independently
To reduce the number of wires

questions.explanation_correct: Appliances in homes are connected in parallel so that each one gets the full voltage and can work independently. This means if one appliance is turned off, the others can still work without any issues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Appliances are not connected in series because in a series circuit, if one appliance stops working, the entire circuit will stop working. This is not ideal for homes where you want each appliance to work independently. Connecting them in parallel ensures that each one gets the full voltage and can function on its own.

questions.question_text: If the metal body of an appliance becomes live due to a fault, the earth wire:

options.text: Provides a path for current to flow to ground

questions.explanation_correct: If the metal body of an appliance becomes live due to a fault, the earth wire provides a low-resistance path for the current to flow to the ground, preventing the user from getting an electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire does not increase the shock, stop the appliance from working, or increase the voltage. When the metal body becomes live, the earth wire creates a low-resistance path for the current to flow to the ground, which helps protect the user from getting an electric shock.

questions.question_text: Why is a fuse always connected in the live wire and not in the neutral wire?

options.text: So that when it blows, the appliance is disconnected from the high-voltage live wire
Because the neutral wire has no current
Because the neutral wire is thinner

questions.explanation_correct: The fuse is connected in the live wire because when it blows, it disconnects the appliance from the high-voltage live wire, preventing a potentially dangerous situation where the user could get an electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fuse is not connected in the neutral wire because the neutral wire does not carry any current. The live wire carries the main current to the appliance, so the fuse needs to be placed in the live wire to protect the appliance and the user in case of a current overload.

questions.question_text: A 100 W bulb is used for 10 hours daily. In 30 days, it consumes:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 30 units. This is because the power of the bulb is 100 W, and it is used for 10 hours daily. In 30 days, the total energy consumed would be 100 W × 10 h × 30 days = 30,000 Wh = 30 units (1 unit = 1 kWh).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately calculate the energy consumption of the 100 W bulb used for 10 hours daily over 30 days. Option B) 3 units is too low, Option C) 300 units is too high, and Option D) 3000 units is significantly too high. The correct answer of 30 units is calculated by multiplying the power of the bulb (100 W), the daily usage time (10 hours), and the number of days (30).

questions.question_text: If too many appliances are connected to a single socket, it can cause:
questions.explanation_correct: If too many appliances are connected to a single socket, it can cause overloading and a fire hazard. This is because the socket will have to supply more current than it is designed for, which can lead to overheating and possible electrical fires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Connecting too many appliances to a single socket will not lower your electricity bills or improve the performance of the appliances. In fact, it can be dangerous, as it can lead to overloading and a fire hazard. The correct option is that it can cause overloading and a fire hazard, as the socket will have to supply more current than it is designed for.

questions.question_text: Why is the switch always connected in the live wire?

options.text: So that when off, the appliance is safe from high voltage
Because neutral wire cannot be switched

questions.explanation_correct: The switch is connected in the live wire so that when the switch is off, the appliance is safely disconnected from the high voltage in the live wire. This protects users from electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The switch is not connected in the live wire to complete the circuit or increase current flow. The neutral wire is not switched because it is the return path for the current. Connecting the switch in the live wire ensures the appliance is safely disconnected when the switch is off, preventing electric shock.

questions.question_text: Appliances with metal bodies require earthing because:

options.text: Metal conducts electricity and may give shock if it becomes live

questions.explanation_correct: Appliances with metal bodies require earthing because metal is a good conductor of electricity. If the metal body becomes live due to a fault, it can give an electric shock to the user. Earthing provides a low-resistance path to the ground, preventing the user from getting shocked.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal appliances do not require earthing just because metal is expensive, rusts easily, or is heavy. The main reason is that metal is a good conductor of electricity. If the metal body becomes live due to a fault in the appliance, it can give an electric shock to the user. Earthing is necessary to provide a low-resistance path to the ground, keeping the user safe.

questions.question_text: An electric iron rated 1100 W is used for 2 hours. If electricity costs Rs. 5 per unit, the cost of running the iron is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Rs. 11. To calculate the cost, we need to multiply the power rating of the iron (1100 W) by the number of hours used (2 hours), which gives us the total energy consumed (2.2 kWh). Since electricity costs Rs. 5 per unit, the total cost of running the iron for 2 hours is Rs. 11.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are: A) Rs. 5, C) Rs. 22, and D) Rs. 55. Option A is incorrect because the cost of running the iron for 2 hours is more than Rs. 5. Option C is incorrect because it assumes the iron was used for 4 hours, not 2 hours. Option D is incorrect because it assumes the iron was used for 11 hours, not 2 hours. The correct answer is B) Rs. 11, which is the cost of running the iron for 2 hours at a rate of Rs. 5 per unit.

questions.question_text: An appliance rated 220 V, 1100 W draws a current of:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 5 A. This is because the power (P) of an appliance is equal to the voltage (V) multiplied by the current (I). So if the voltage is 220 V and the power is 1100 W, the current drawn by the appliance is 1100 W / 220 V = 5 A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not match the formula for calculating the current drawn by an appliance. The formula is P = V × I, where P is the power, V is the voltage, and I is the current. So if the power is 1100 W and the voltage is 220 V, the current must be 1100 W / 220 V = 5 A, which is option A.

questions.question_text: A family uses a 2 kW heater for 3 hours daily. The monthly (30 days) electricity consumption is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 180 units. This is because the heater uses 2 kW of power and is used for 3 hours daily. For 30 days, the total energy consumption would be 2 kW x 3 hours x 30 days = 180 units.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not take into account the power rating of the heater (2 kW) and the duration of use (3 hours daily for 30 days). Option A) 60 units is too low, option C) 6 units is too low, and option D) 18 units is too low. The correct answer is B) 180 units, which takes into account the total energy consumption of the heater over the 30-day period.

questions.question_text: The live wire carries current to the appliance.
questions.explanation_correct: The live wire carries the electric current to the appliance, powering it. This is the wire that completes the circuit and allows electricity to flow through the appliance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The neutral wire, not the live wire, is the one that carries the current back to the power source. The live wire provides the voltage that powers the appliance, while the neutral wire completes the circuit by returning the current to the source.

questions.question_text: A circuit breaker needs to be replaced after it trips.
questions.explanation_correct: A circuit breaker does not need to be replaced after it trips. It is designed to automatically turn off the electrical supply when the current exceeds a safe limit, protecting the circuit and appliances. After the issue that caused the tripping is fixed, the circuit breaker can simply be reset to restore power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that a circuit breaker needs to be replaced after it trips. However, this is not the case. Circuit breakers are safety devices that are meant to break the circuit when the current becomes dangerously high, in order to prevent damage to the electrical system and appliances. After the problem that caused the tripping is resolved, the circuit breaker can be reset to restore power, without needing to be replaced.

questions.question_text: In parallel connection, all appliances get the same voltage.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel connection, all appliances are connected to the same voltage supply. This means that each appliance gets the full 220V of the household electricity, allowing them to work independently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a parallel connection, the voltage across each appliance is the same. This is because they are all connected to the same voltage source, which is the household electricity supply of 220V. Each appliance can work independently at this full voltage, unlike a series connection where the voltage would be divided across the appliances.

questions.question_text: The earth wire normally carries current during normal operation.
questions.explanation_correct: The earth wire is not meant to carry current during normal operation. Its purpose is to provide a low-resistance path to the ground in case of a fault, like a short circuit or electrical leakage. This helps protect users from getting an electric shock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The earth wire is not part of the main circuit that carries the current to power household appliances. It is a safety feature that remains virtually current-free during normal operation. If the earth wire carried current, it would defeat its purpose of providing a low-resistance path to the ground in case of a fault.

questions.question_text: Using a fuse of higher rating than required is dangerous.
questions.explanation_correct: Using a fuse with a higher rating than required is dangerous because it will not be able to cut off the circuit in case of an overload or short circuit. The fuse is designed to break the circuit when the current exceeds a safe limit. A higher-rated fuse will allow too much current to flow, which can damage the appliance or even cause a fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fuse with a higher rating may seem like it would offer more protection, but that is not the case. A higher-rated fuse will not be able to cut off the circuit in time if there is an overload or short circuit. The fuse needs to be rated for the specific appliance or circuit to ensure it can break the connection safely when the current is too high. Using a fuse with a lower rating than required is also dangerous, as it may trip too easily and disrupt the circuit.

questions.question_text: If appliances were connected in series, switching off one would switch off all others.
questions.explanation_correct: If appliances were connected in series, switching off one appliance would cut the power supply to all the other appliances connected in the same circuit. This is because in a series circuit, the current is the same through each component.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a household electrical system, appliances are connected in parallel, not series. This means each appliance has its own connection to the power source and can work independently. Switching off one appliance would not affect the others, as they each receive the full 220V supply.

questions.question_text: The domestic electricity supply in India is ___ current (AC).
questions.explanation_correct: The domestic electricity supply in India is alternating current (AC) because the flow of electric charge in the circuit constantly changes direction, unlike direct current (DC) where the flow is in one direction. AC power is commonly used in households and for electrical grids because it is more efficient for transmission over long distances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The domestic electricity supply in India is not direct current (DC), which is a constant flow of electric charge in one direction. The accepted answer is 'alternating', which refers to the flow of electric charge in the circuit constantly changing direction. This is the type of current used in Indian households, not direct current.

questions.question_text: The ___ wire carries current from the appliance back to the mains.
questions.explanation_correct: The neutral wire carries the current back to the mains (power source) after the appliance has used it. This completes the circuit and allows the electricity to flow continuously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The live wire, not the neutral wire, carries the current from the appliance back to the mains. The neutral wire is used to complete the circuit and provide a path for the current to return to the power source. The correct answer is 'neutral'.

questions.question_text: A ___ is a safety device that can be reset after tripping.
questions.explanation_correct: A circuit breaker is a safety device that can be reset after tripping, unlike a fuse which needs to be replaced. Circuit breakers automatically disconnect the circuit when the current becomes too high, protecting the wiring and appliances from damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'circuit breaker'. A circuit breaker is a safety device that can be reset after it 'trips' or turns off the power, unlike a fuse which needs to be replaced. When the current in a circuit gets too high, the circuit breaker will automatically break the circuit to prevent damage, and can then be switched back on once the problem is fixed.

questions.question_text: Appliances in homes are connected in ___ so each gets full voltage.
questions.explanation_correct: Appliances in homes are connected in parallel because each appliance gets the full 220V voltage and can work independently. This is better than connecting them in series, where a single break would stop all appliances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Appliances in homes are not connected in series. If they were, each appliance would only get a fraction of the 220V voltage and would not work properly. The correct answer is 'parallel', where each appliance is directly connected to the 220V supply and can function independently.

questions.question_text: Power (in watts) equals voltage multiplied by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'current' because the power (P) of an electrical circuit is calculated by multiplying the voltage (V) by the current (I). This relationship is expressed by the formula P = V × I, which means that power is directly proportional to the current flowing through the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'resistance'. While resistance (R) is an important electrical quantity, the power formula is P = V × I, not P = V × R. The current is the amount of electric charge flowing through the circuit per unit time, and it is this current that determines the power consumption of an electrical appliance, not the resistance.

questions.question_text: When live and neutral wires touch directly, a ___ circuit occurs.
questions.explanation_correct: When the live and neutral wires touch directly, it creates a short circuit. This means the current can flow directly from the live wire to the neutral wire without going through the appliance. This excess flow of current can be very dangerous and cause fires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'short'. When the live and neutral wires touch directly, it creates a short circuit. This means the current can flow directly from the live wire to the neutral wire without going through the appliance. This excess flow of current can be very dangerous and cause fires. The other possible answer, 'open', refers to a situation where the circuit is broken and no current can flow, which is not the case when live and neutral wires touch directly.

questions.question_text: A 500 W appliance used for 4 hours consumes ___ units of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: The appliance consumes 500 watts of power and is used for 4 hours. To calculate the energy consumed, we multiply the power (500 watts) by the time (4 hours), which gives us 2000 watt-hours or 2 units of electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the appliance consumes 500 watts of power and is used for 4 hours, the total energy consumed would be 2000 watt-hours, which is equal to 2 units of electricity. The accepted answer format for this question is a single number, so the correct answer is 2 units.

questions.question_text: Current (in amperes) equals power divided by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is 'voltage' because the formula for electric current (I) is power (P) divided by voltage (V), or I = P/V. This means that if you know the power of an appliance and the voltage it is connected to, you can calculate the current it will use.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to leave the blank empty. This is because the current in an electrical circuit is determined by the power of the appliance and the voltage of the power supply, not just the power alone. The formula for electric current is I = P/V, where I is the current in amperes, P is the power in watts, and V is the voltage in volts.

questions.question_text: Arrange the three wires in order of their importance for safety:
questions.explanation_correct: The Earth wire is the most important for safety as it provides a low-resistance path to the ground, protecting you from electric shocks if there is a fault in the appliance. The Live wire carries the main electrical current, while the Neutral wire completes the circuit. So the order of importance for safety is Earth, Live, Neutral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Live wire is not the most important for safety. While it carries the main electrical current, if there is a fault, the Live wire can give you a dangerous electric shock. The Earth wire is the most important, as it provides a safe path to the ground, protecting you from shocks. The correct order of importance for safety is Earth, Live, Neutral.

questions.question_text: Arrange the sequence of events when earthing protects from a fault:
ordering_items: Fault causes metal body to become live
Current flows through earth wire to ground
correct_answer: Fault causes metal body to become live
Current flows through earth wire to ground
questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: Fault causes metal body to become live, Current flows through earth wire to ground, Fuse blows, circuit breaks. This is because the earth wire provides a low-resistance path for the current to flow to the ground, preventing the user from getting an electric shock. The high current flow then causes the fuse to blow and break the circuit, making the appliance safe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect sequence would be: Fuse blows, circuit breaks, Fault causes metal body to become live, Current flows through earth wire to ground. This is wrong because the fault needs to occur first, causing the metal body to become live. The current then flows through the earth wire to the ground, before the fuse blows and breaks the circuit. The earth wire is crucial in providing a safe path for the current, preventing electric shock.

questions.question_text: Arrange these appliances from lowest to highest power consumption:
questions.explanation_correct: The LED bulb has the lowest power consumption of 10W, followed by the ceiling fan at 75W, and the electric iron has the highest power consumption of 1000W. This is because different electrical appliances require different amounts of electrical power to function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Ceiling fan (75W), LED bulb (10W), Electric iron (1000W). This is not correct because the electric iron, which is used for heating, requires much more power (1000W) than the ceiling fan (75W) and the LED bulb (10W), which are used for other purposes. The appliances must be arranged from lowest to highest power consumption.

questions.question_text: Arrange these fuse ratings from smallest to largest:
questions.explanation_correct: The fuse ratings are arranged from smallest to largest as 5 A, 15 A, 30 A. This is because the lower the fuse rating, the less current it can safely handle before breaking the circuit, while higher fuse ratings can handle more current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fuse ratings should not be arranged as 15 A, 5 A, 30 A. This is incorrect because the fuse ratings need to be in ascending order from smallest to largest. The correct order is 5 A, 15 A, 30 A, as the lower the fuse rating, the less current it can safely handle before breaking the circuit.
